items.content_html:
Issue number that this PR fixes (if any). For example: 'Fixes #987654321'

N/A

What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

Doc for BigInt said (capitalization mine),
"You can obtain the SAFEST value that can be incremented with Numbers by using the constant {{jsxref("Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER")}}."
I think it's supposed to say,
"You can obtain the LARGEST SAFE value that can be incremented with Numbers by using the constant {{jsxref("Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER")}}.

Anything else that could help us review it
items.title: Fixed typo

items.content_html:
Fixes #7810

This property is a bit unusual, however as far as web developers are concerned it can be set, although by passing a string, not the object that is returned.

https://drafts.csswg.org/cssom/#the-cssimportrule-interface
items.title: Clarify the CSSImportRule.media property

items.content_html: We're starting to see an increasing number of prs with large grammer updates which change the meaning of the content and are difficult to review. This adds a note in the readme to address this for the future
items.title: Updating readme to reflect large grammer updates

items.content_html: Making content ready to convert to md.
items.title: Update WebXR guides for Markdown conversion

items.content_html: Mostly removal of "summary" and "seo-summary" classes but also some table fixes and fixing notecard divs.
items.title: Update WebXR reference pages for markdown

items.content_html:
These are large tables that are not really nice to consult.

  • I removed the columns Comments and put the few comments below the tables. This shortens the width of a lot of them (but not all).
  • I merged UA and its version in the first column, this makes the table more readable and removed the need for rowspan attributes that are not supported by MD tables.

The info in the table is quite outdated, but this will be fixed later; I wanted to keep this PR as technical as possible.

Bookkeeping: This is part of #7536.
items.title: Fix tables for Markdown conversion in List of default `Accept` values

items.content_html:
This fixes the tables in Browser detection using the user agent and allows the document to be translated in Markdown.

Besides technical fixes, I removed the fourth column when there was one. It was usually either simple comments or empty cells.

A few of these tables are still large, and I may decide to represent them differently in the future; I'll revisit these when I'll complete them, as they are a bit outdated.

This is part of #7536.
items.title: Fix tables in Browser detection using UA (for md)

items.content_html:
This makes most tables in Web/HTTP compatible with the Markdown conversion script.

  • I removed all the standard-table classes.
  • Some are just adapted (updating the <th>, removing the scope attributes, removing the rowspan, often by repeating the info.
  • Some tables have been broken into sub-tables, between headings, to remove the first column.
  • A couple were old-style specification tables that I converted to the new style, compatible with md.

Properties tables are not dealt with here (I will keep them)

After this, there are still two documents with tables to convert, but they will be in a separate PR as they are more complex.

For bookkeeping purposes: this is part of #7536.
items.title: Update (most) tables to be md compatible in Web/HTTP

items.content_html:
This draft PR converts all CSS docs (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS and everything under it) to Markdown.

Conversion

The conversion report is at https://gist.github.com/wbamberg/90c2da5ffc28daf5b2ef5a39165884e3 . I converted it using a version of h2m which has mdn/yari#4444, which means it understands SVG syntax highlighting.

The main thing here as usual is tables. I count 57 unconverted tables out of (I think) 175 tables in the CSS docs. This is actually a much better ratio than the JS docs, in which I think around half were unconvertible. See for example https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Values_and_Units for some simple tables that got converted.

Apart from these, unconverted elements were:

  • <kbd> elements, which we had agreed to keep as HTML
  • id attributes for the four tools pages. These pages use EmbedLiveSample in a very unconventional way, to implement essentially complete web apps. Since these don't have headings, we can't use heading IDs for the live sample. And since they are not really "content" it doesn't seem very important to convert them. The pages concerned are:
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Background_and_Borders/Border-image_generator,
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Colors/Color_picker_tool
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Background_and_Borders/Box-shadow_generator
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Background_and_Borders/Border-radius_generator
  • a dir="rtl" attribute which seemed like it would be worth keeping, in the example at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/letter-spacing#internationalization_concerns. But maybe this should be made into a live sample? Anyway, it's a tiny thing.

Testing

I've not looked at every page but I have looked at quite a lot of them. I have found a few issues.

  • sometimes, <dl> elements are getting mangled in conversion. I filed a bug about this: mdn/yari#4445. It would be good to have this fixed, but the in-content fix is very simple and I think there are very few pages affected. So I would be OK to work around these in content for now. Affected pages (that I have found) are:

    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/basic-shape#shape_functions
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/url()#values
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@counter-style#descriptors

  • the tools pages listed above are broken, I think because the encoding of characters like < in the live sample is confusing the converter. Ideally these pages would be part of the core Yari platform and not content pages at all. A less good option that's still better than what we have now would be to make them GitHub pages and include them using EmbedGHLiveSample. In the meantime I would be happy to keep these as HTML - they're not exactly editable anyway, so we don't really lose anything that way.

  • the code elements in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-position#regarding_percentages are not being wrapped, and that's breaking the page layout. I haven't tried to figure out what's happening there yet.
items.title: CSS to Markdown

items.content_html:

Accessibility_inspector

Usually color blind people can't distinguish colors but they are good at distinguishing specific color.

Anything else that could help us review it
items.title: Fix mistakes from Accessibility_inspector

items.content_html:
This is part of fixing #3196 - replaces a page inclusion macro of the EffectTiming dictionary properties into the two places it is used: Element.animate(), KeyframeEffect()

I would like to update further, perhaps as a post process. To help with that, answers to the following would be great.

  1. There is also KeyframeEffectReadOnly() that redirects to KeyframeEffect() and a AnimationEffectReadOnly which we don't document. I can't see in spec but they do appear in https://docs1.w3cub.com/haxe~javascript/html/animationeffectreadonly/ . Is it "valid" or are these things that no longer really exist?
  2. The EffectTiming dictionary should be removed altogether but I'm not quite sure how to deal with it:
    • The properties have sub-docs which I presume I can pull in most of. That would be painful but is doable.
    • What concerns me is that the thing has its own BCD https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EffectTiming#properties that is not included in the Element.animate() compatibility. I presume the action here is to update that with each of these options?
items.title: Pagemacro: include rather than transclude EffectTiming properties

items.content_html:
Changed the Card expiry date format which was eariler in "mm/dd/yyyy" to "=MM/YY".

Fixes #2537.

items.content_html:
The replacement code for "Simplifying list selectors" can use an :if as the last selector instead of having a comma-separated list of complex selectors.

If it's felt that we should show the 3 separate selectors for clarity, then I would suggest adding <p>Or even...</p> followed by the sorter code example.
